Contradict fact: The claim that NASA confirms Earth will experience 15 days of darkness in November 2017 contradicts the fact that NASA has not made such an announcement.
Exaggerate: The claim exaggerates the duration of darkness, stating it will last for 15 days, whereas there is no evidence to support this.
Lack enough support: The claim lacks enough support as it does not provide any official sources or evidence from NASA to back up the statement.
Problematic assumption: The claim assumes that there will be a blackout event causing darkness for 15 days in November 2017, which is not based on any factual information.
Exist alternative explanation: The claim does not provide any alternative explanations or consider other possible reasons for the alleged event, such as the alignment of Venus and Jupiter or a hydrogen explosion in space.
Falters at times: The claim falters at times by providing inaccurate information, such as quoting a former NASA administrator who had already resigned before the alleged announcement.
Understate: There is no evidence of understating in the claim as it makes an exaggerated and false statement rather than downplaying any information.
